units.title: Generation of cerebral organoids and ALI-COs
units.text: Generation of cerebral organoids and ALI-COs. For the generation of hiPSC-derived COs cultured at the ALI, we modified a previously published method5 utilizing a STEMdiff Cerebral Organoid kit (StemCell Technologies, 08570). Briefly, 18,000 cells were plated in the presence of poly(lactide-co-glycolide) copolymer microfilaments to achieve improved cortical development58. Initially, media changes were performed at days 3, 5 and 7, then every 3–4 days. From 35 DIV onwards, Matrigel (Corning, 354234) was added in 1:50 dilution to achieve a polarized cortical plate formation. Between 50 and 80 DIV, 300-μm thick ALI-CO cultures were prepared for subsequent long-term cultures on Millicell-CM (Merck Millipore, PICM0RG50) inserts and were fed daily with slice medium containing neurobasal medium (ThermoFisher Scientific, 21103049) supplemented with 1× B27 supplement (ThermoFisher Scientific, 17504044), 0.45% (w/v) glucose (Sigma-Aldrich, G8769), Glutamax (ThermoFisher Scientific, 35050038) and 1% antibiotic–antimycotic.
units.rationale: Describes how to produce the organoid model used in downstream experiments.

units.title: Immunocytochemistry
units.text: Immunocytochemistry. ALI-COs and whole organoids at 30 and 75 DIV were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 45 min, 2 or 4 h, respectively, washed slices at room temperature. Fixed samples were prepared as frozen blocks for cryostat sectioning, and 12-μm thick frozen sections were immunostained with antibodies (Supplementary Table 2) using our published protocols61. After immunofluorescence-based detection of DDR in hiPSCs, cells were seeded on 1% Geltrex-coated coverslips 24 h before treatment (Geltrex, Thermo Fisher Scientific, 0.5 mg ml−1) and then washed in PBS followed by fixation in 2% PFA (Alfa Aesar) for 15 min at room temperature, then washed again three times in PBS. The cell pellet was resuspended in 0.5% Triton X-100 (Sigma-Aldrich, T8787) for 10 min, before blocking at room temperature for 1 h in 5% BSA (w/v; Sigma, A9647), followed by primary antibody (in 5% BSA PBST) incubation overnight at 4 °C. Cells were incubated with secondary antibody (in 5% BSA PBST) for 1 h at room temperature and were counterstained with 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI; 0.2 mg ml−1) and then mounted using Fluoromount-G (Affymetrix eBioscience, 15586276).
units.rationale: Provides the stepwise protocol for labeling proteins in organoid sections.

units.title: Real-time cell vulnerability assay
units.text: Real-time cell vulnerability assay. Six-well plates (Appleton Woods, Corning, CC010) were coated with 1% Geltrex (Thermo Fisher Scientific, A1413302) in DMEM/F-12 (Fisher Scientific, Gibco, 11514436). hiPSCs were seeded in StemMACS iPS-Brew XF (Miltenyi Biotec, 130-104-368) medium at a density of 1 × 10^5 cells per well. After 24 h, the survival assay was performed in IncuCyte S3 Live-Cell Analysis system (Sartorius, 4647). Cells were either left untreated or treated daily with 1.25 nM, 2.5 nM, 5 nM or 10 nM topotecan (Apexbio, B2296). Images were acquired every 6 h over a duration of 5 days using a ×10 magnification objective and cell confluency was determined as a cell body cluster area by the IncuCyte NeuroTrack software.
units.rationale: Details how to monitor cell survival under drug treatment in real time.

units.title: Alkaline comet assay
units.text: Alkaline comet assay. The alkaline comet assay was performed to compare DNA accumulation and repair in control and C9 ALS/FTD hiPSC lines60. Cells were seeded overnight before topotecan (10 μM for 1 h) treatment in the presence or absence of an ATMi (Selleck Chemicals, AZD0156, 30 nM). Half of the plates were trypsinized (0.25%, Sigma-Aldrich, T4049) for 1 h. The cells were then resuspended in 1× PBS (Mg/Ca-free) at 2 × 10^5 cells per ml, mixed in 500 μl LMAgarose (Trevigen, 4250-050-02; melted for 5 min at 100 °C and kept at 37 °C), then 70 μl of the mixture was pipetted on preheated 1% agarose-coated glass slides (37 °C). The slides were subjected to electrophoresis at 35 V for 10 min in the alkaline electrophoresis solution (200 mM NaOH, 1 mM EDTA, pH > 13). After fixation with 70% ethanol and drying at 37 °C, slides were stained with SYBR green I (Invitrogen, D2650). Tail percentage was measured using the OpenComet plugin for ImageJ (>50 cells per condition).
units.rationale: Outlines the procedure to assess DNA damage levels in cells.

units.title: Southern blotting
units.text: Southern blotting. DNA was extracted from the hiPSC cultures using a Qiagen DNeasy Blood and Tissue kit (69506). DNA (5 µg) was restriction digested with Bsu36I (New England Biolabs, R0524S) and ran on 0.8% agarose gels accompanied by molecular weight markers II (Roche, 11218590910) and III (Roche, 11218603910). Southern blotting was performed according to published protocols68 using a 1-kb probe (Prepared by IDT; sequence: GGGGCC) in salmon sperm DNA for hybridization and an anti-DIG AP antibody (Roche, 11093274910) for visualization.
units.rationale: Provides the steps to detect repeat expansions by Southern blot.

units.title: DNA damage detection
units.text: DNA damage detection. DNA damage accumulation was assessed by DNA immunolabeling for γ-H2AX or 53BP1 (refs. 43,65). hiPSCs were seeded overnight on coverslips (Academy, NPC16/13) coated with 1% Geltrex (ThermoFisher Scientific, A1413302; diluted in DMEM/F-12, Fisher Scientific, Gibco, 11514436). Coverslips were washed with PBS containing 0.1 % Tween-20 (PBST) and were fixed with 2% PFA (w/v; Alfa Aesar, 43368) for 10 min. After washing, cells were permeabilized with 0.5% Triton X-100 (Sigma-Aldrich, T8787) for 10 min, blocked with 5% BSA (w/v; Sigma, A9647) for 1 h, incubated with primary antibody in 5% BSA PBST overnight at 4 °C, followed by secondary antibody for 1 h at room temperature, and finally mounted for imaging.
units.rationale: Describes immunostaining to visualize DNA damage markers.

units.title: Repeat-primed PCR
units.text: Repeat-primed PCR. DNA was extracted from samples using a QIAamp DNA Mini kit (Qiagen, 51306), and the C9ORF72 locus amplified by PCR with the 6-FAM-labeled forward and reverse primers (see below) as previously described69. Forward primer: MRX-F1: FAM-TGTAAAACGACGGCCAGTCAAGGAGGGAAACAACCGCAGCC; Reverse primer: MRX-R: CAGGAAACAGCTATGACCGGGCCCGCCCCGA. The PCR product was denatured and analyzed by capillary electrophoresis on an Applied Bioscience 3730XL DNA Analyzer (Thermo), and chromatographs were aligned in GeneMapper v.6. software (Thermo).
units.rationale: Details the assay used to size the C9ORF72 repeat expansion.

units.title: MEA recordings
units.text: MEA recordings. ALI-COs were secured with a platinum harp onto 3D MEAs (Multi Channel Systems, MEA2100, 60–3DMEA200/12iR-Ti-gr, 60 electrodes, 200-μm spacing). Six-minute-long recordings of spontaneous activity at 37 °C (n = 35 ALI-COs) were acquired and exported to Matlab (MathWorks) for analysis. The raw signal was bandpass-filtered (third-order Butterworth, 600–8,000 Hz) and spikes detected using a threshold of 3 standard deviations above background noise with a 1.5‑ms refractory period. Correlated activity between electrodes was analyzed using the spike‑time tiling coefficient (STTC) with a synchronicity window of 175 ms.
units.rationale: Provides the workflow for electrophysiological measurement of organoid activity.

units.title: scRNA‑seq pipeline and analysis
units.text: scRNA‑seq pipeline and analysis. The initial scRNA‑seq data‑analysis pipeline was generated using the CellRanger 3.1 software package according to our published protocols5. Reads were aligned to the GRCh38 human genome. CellRanger detected 85% fraction reads on average per cell and 1,600–2,100 median genes per cell. Data were processed in Seurat 3.1/4.0.1 and filtered based on a minimum of three cells expressing each gene and a mitochondrial gene proportion below 25%. Clustering was performed in Seurat over 14 dimensions with a resolution of 0.4, yielding 233 whole COs and 587 ALI‑CO slices. Batch correction was applied using canonical correlation analysis, and trajectory reconstruction was performed with Monocle 3 (v.0.2.3.0).
units.rationale: Summarizes the computational steps for single‑cell transcriptomic analysis.

units.title: Statistics and reproducibility
units.text: Statistics and reproducibility. The subject identifiers were blinded for the observers. Details of statistical tests and exact sample sizes are listed in Supplementary Table 3. Briefly, the sample sizes using hiPSC lines and organoids were estimated from previously performed experiments5,61. In total, 233 whole COs were used for this study, and 587 ALI‑CO slices were grown deriving from 99 independent whole organoids. At least three independent biological replicates were used per group for all statistical analyses in biological experiments. The GraphPad software (GraphPad Prism v.7.0/8.0) was used for distribution analysis, statistical analysis and for generating graphs. When normality was not assumed, non‑parametric tests were used. Overall analysis of variance (ANOVA) P value is presented; cases where no statistical difference was found between more than two groups, the overall ANOVA P value is presented.
units.rationale: Outlines how data were analyzed and how reproducibility was ensured.
